title.narrative: From farm to landscape: capacity building, dialogue and action with multiple stakeholders in Honduras (Zona Litoral del Norte)

description.narrative:
The Paisajes Sostenibles (PaSos) platform joined producer organizations, private sector actors, local communities, CSOs and public sector actors to identify solutions for complex and interconnected issues, such as biodiversity conservation, sustainable production, climate change and land use change. PaSos formed a space for dialogue, and worked towards policy recommendations for improved spatial planning and responsible expansion of palm oil based on RSPO certification. Through the pilots we showed how well-managed palm oil plantations can play a crucial role in flora and fauna conservation and the preservation of several species. This conservation practice was scaled up to 3 palm oil companies (25% of the sector). One of the main successes of the PaSos Platform was the negotiation and signing of the first Zero Deforestation Declaration of Mesoamerica; 100% of the palm oil sector signed the declaration together with local CSOs, and national-level government actors. Together with the Honduran Minister of the Institute for Conservation of Forests and Biodiversity (ICF) we are looking into the possibilities to expand this Declaration to include coffee and livestock.
Via PaSos, we developed an agroforestry initiative to enhance women participation in sustainable cocoa production. The initiative benefitted 112 families and introduced agroforestry cocoa on 300 hectares. New partnerships with private and public partners were developed to further support the agroforestry initiative by providing seedlings, funds and training and so accelerate the restoration process, crucial after the two hurricanes occurred in 2020.

title.narrative: # of mechanisms, policies and regulations implemented by government bodies

comment.narrative: In addition to the 3 results in 2017 (conservation mechanisms to protect the flora and fauna in biological corridors, land titling for small palm producers in Colon department, Inputs to the Law of reforestation incentives) the Manual of Good Farm Practices adapted for small oil palm producers was co-produced in cooperation with FENAPALMAH, SAG and Mi Ambiente.

comment.narrative: Atlantic littoral zone north of Honduras

title.narrative: # of pilots consortia developed to test landscape solutions

comment.narrative: Progress was made in the following way with the pilots: 1) Connectivity was consolidated with the addition of 2 companies and 34,000 H������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������s. linked to 2 protected areas. 2) The PASOS Honduras program was linked to the SDGs, identifying that it is linked to 11 SDGs (1,5,6, 7, 8,10, 12, 14, 15, 16 and 17). The current UNDP program is linked to 7 SDGs (1,5,8,9,10,12,17). We agree on 5 of the 7 of the UNDP and this will be determined by Solidaridad participation in the GEF 6 and 7 program. 3) WWF has advanced (2017-18) in georeferencing at least 700 small palm producers. 4) REDMUCH leads cocoa cultivation processes for about 150 hectares. and above all postharvest, forming chocolate women at 2 levels: Artisan and Gourmet. 5) The Finacial Tools was elaborated and shared for improvement in a Workshop but then there was no continuity due to changes to the Impact Investment strategy and because it was not adequate. 6) The land titling process with INA (National Agrarian Institute) was delayed due to instability of the governmental partner (INA) and it was decided to re pose the project at the local regional level (Tocoa and San Pedro Sula) and also expanded to Cacao and Rambutan.
